questions.question: What Git command is used to create a new local repository?
questions.why_correct: git init initializes a new Git repository in the current directory.

why_incorrect.a: git start is not a valid Git command.
why_incorrect.c: git create is not an actual Git command.
why_incorrect.d: git new is not a recognized Git command.

questions.question: Which command downloads a repository from GitHub to your local machine?
questions.why_correct: git clone copies a remote repository and creates a new local repository.

why_incorrect.a: git download is not a standard Git command.
why_incorrect.c: git fetch only retrieves changes into the local repo; it does not create a new one.
why_incorrect.d: git pull updates an existing local repo from a remote; it does not clone a new one.

questions.question: What is the purpose of a .gitignore file?

choices.a: To list contributors to the repository
choices.b: To specify files that Git should ignore

questions.why_correct: A .gitignore file lists patterns for files and directories that Git should not track.

why_incorrect.a: Contributors are tracked via commits or repository metadata, not .gitignore.
why_incorrect.c: GitHub Actions workflows are defined in YAML files under .github/workflows.
why_incorrect.d: Git configuration settings are stored in config files, not .gitignore.

questions.question: What is the correct sequence in Test-Driven Development?

choices.b: Design tests, write code, test code
choices.d: Design architecture, write tests, implement code

questions.why_correct: TDD follows the Red-Green-Refactor cycle: write failing tests, write code to pass them, then refactor.

why_incorrect.a: This sequence writes code before tests, which is the opposite of TDD.
why_incorrect.b: This is a generic flow, not the strict TDD cycle; TDD emphasizes starting with failing tests.
why_incorrect.d: Architecture design is not explicitly part of the TDD red-green-refactor loop.

questions.question: Which statement about unit tests is true?

choices.a: They test the entire application as a whole
choices.b: They test individual components in isolation
choices.c: They only test the user interface

questions.why_correct: Unit tests are focused on testing small, isolated pieces of code, like individual functions or classes.

why_incorrect.a: Testing the entire application is closer to system or end-to-end testing, not unit testing.
why_incorrect.c: Unit tests can cover any layer of the system, not just the UI.
why_incorrect.d: Unit tests should avoid production databases and typically use mocks or test databases.

questions.question: Which SQL statement selects all columns from a table named "users"?
questions.why_correct: SELECT * FROM users selects all columns from the users table.

why_incorrect.a: This omits the FROM keyword and is not valid SQL.
why_incorrect.b: SELECT ALL FROM users is not standard SQL syntax.
why_incorrect.d: SELECT COLUMNS FROM users is not valid SQL syntax.

questions.question: In SQL, which command adds a new record to a table?
questions.why_correct: INSERT is the SQL command used to add new rows to a table.

why_incorrect.a: ADD is not used to insert rows into tables in standard SQL.
why_incorrect.c: APPEND is not a standard SQL keyword.
why_incorrect.d: CREATE is used to create databases or tables, not new records.

questions.question: What does REST stand for in RESTful API?
questions.why_correct: REST stands for Representational State Transfer, an architectural style for designing networked applications.

why_incorrect.a: Reactive State Transfer is not the correct term.
why_incorrect.c: Resource Standard Transfer is not a standard phrase in this context.
why_incorrect.d: Remote Execution Service Technology is unrelated to the REST acronym.

questions.question: Which HTTP status code indicates a successful request?
questions.why_correct: HTTP 200 OK indicates a successful HTTP request.

why_incorrect.b: 404 indicates that the requested resource was not found.
why_incorrect.c: 500 indicates an internal server error.
why_incorrect.d: 302 indicates a temporary redirect, not direct success.

questions.question: What is the correct syntax for JSON objects?
questions.why_correct: JSON requires keys to be in double quotes and uses colons for key-value pairs.

why_incorrect.a: Keys must be in double quotes in valid JSON.
why_incorrect.c: JSON does not use '='; it uses ':' between keys and values.
why_incorrect.d: JSON uses ':' not '=' between keys and values.

questions.question: What is the primary purpose of a linter?

choices.b: To identify coding errors and style issues
choices.c: To compile code into executable files

questions.why_correct: Linters analyze source code to detect errors, bugs, and style inconsistencies.

why_incorrect.a: Performance optimization is not the primary purpose of a linter.
why_incorrect.c: Compiling code is done by compilers or build tools, not linters.
why_incorrect.d: Dependency management is handled by package managers, not linters.

questions.question: What is the main purpose of a precommit hook?

choices.b: To run tests or linters before allowing a commit
choices.c: To create a new branch for each commit

questions.why_correct: Pre-commit hooks allow checks like tests or linters to run before a commit is finalized.

why_incorrect.a: Pre-commit hooks do not automatically commit; they run before a manual commit.
why_incorrect.c: They do not create branches; branching is a separate Git operation.
why_incorrect.d: They do not sync with remote repositories; that is done with push/pull.

questions.question: Which HTML tag is used to define an unordered list?
questions.why_correct: <ul> defines an unordered (bulleted) list in HTML.

why_incorrect.a: <ol> defines an ordered (numbered) list.
why_incorrect.c: <list> is not a standard HTML tag.
why_incorrect.d: <dl> defines a description list, not an unordered list.

questions.question: What does the HTML <meta> tag do?

choices.b: Provides metadata about the HTML document

questions.why_correct: <meta> provides metadata (like charset, description, viewport) about the document.

why_incorrect.a: Metadata is not directly visible to users.
why_incorrect.c: <meta> does not create animations.
why_incorrect.d: External JavaScript is linked using <script>, not <meta>.

questions.question: Which HTML5 element represents a standalone section of content?
questions.why_correct: <article> represents a self-contained, independent piece of content.

why_incorrect.a: <div> is a generic container with no semantic meaning.
why_incorrect.b: <span> is an inline container, not a standalone content section.
why_incorrect.d: <content> is not a standard HTML5 element.

questions.question: What is the purpose of the HTML <form> element?
questions.why_correct: <form> is used to collect user input and submit it to a server.

why_incorrect.a: Formatted text is handled by various text tags, not specifically <form>.
why_incorrect.c: Importing external HTML is not done with <form>.
why_incorrect.d: <footer> defines a footer, not <form>.

questions.question: Which attribute is required for an HTML tag?
questions.why_correct: The src attribute specifies the image source URL and is required.

why_incorrect.a: title is optional and provides advisory information.
why_incorrect.c: alt is strongly recommended for accessibility but not strictly required by the parser.
why_incorrect.d: width is optional for styling and layout.

questions.question: What does the HTML <!DOCTYPE> declaration do?

choices.a: Declares the document as an HTML file
choices.b: Links to an external document type
choices.c: Tells the browser what version of HTML the page is written in

questions.why_correct: <!DOCTYPE> tells the browser which HTML standard to use for rendering.

why_incorrect.a: It does more than just declare the document type; it signals standard mode.
why_incorrect.b: It does not link to an external document type.
why_incorrect.d: It does not create a variable; it's a declaration.

questions.question: What does CSS stand for?
questions.why_correct: CSS stands for Cascading Style Sheets.

why_incorrect.a: Computer Style Sheets is incorrect.
why_incorrect.b: Creative Style System is not the correct expansion.
why_incorrect.d: Colorful Style Sheets is not the correct term.

questions.question: Which CSS property is used to change the text color?
questions.why_correct: The color property controls the text color in CSS.

why_incorrect.b: text-color is not a valid CSS property.
why_incorrect.c: font-color is not a standard CSS property.
why_incorrect.d: text-style is not used for text color.

questions.question: How do you select all paragraph elements in CSS?
questions.why_correct:
Using the element selector p targets all

elements.

why_incorrect.a: #p selects an element with id="p".
why_incorrect.b: .p selects elements with class="p".
why_incorrect.d: all(p) is not valid CSS selector syntax.

questions.question: What is the CSS Box Model?

choices.a: A design pattern for creating boxes
choices.b: A layout model describing content, padding, border, and margin

questions.why_correct: The box model describes how content, padding, border, and margin define the size and spacing of elements.

why_incorrect.a: It is more than just a design pattern; it is a core layout model.
why_incorrect.c: It is not a 3D rendering technique.
why_incorrect.d: It is not a framework but a fundamental concept in CSS.

questions.question: Which CSS property controls the spacing between elements?
questions.why_correct: margin controls the outer space around an element, thus spacing between elements.

why_incorrect.a: space is not a valid CSS property.
why_incorrect.c: padding controls the space between content and its border, not between elements.
why_incorrect.d: gap applies to spacing within flex/grid containers, not generic element spacing in all contexts.

questions.question: What is the purpose of CSS media queries?

choices.a: To query a database for styling information
choices.b: To apply different styles for different devices/screen sizes
choices.c: To import styles from external media

questions.why_correct: Media queries allow CSS rules to be applied conditionally based on device/screen characteristics.

why_incorrect.a: CSS has no direct database querying feature.
why_incorrect.c: @import is used to import styles, not media queries themselves.
why_incorrect.d: Animations are handled by CSS animations and transitions, not media queries.

questions.question: Which statement correctly declares a variable in modern JavaScript?

choices.d: Both b and c are correct

questions.why_correct: Both var and let can be used to declare variables in modern JavaScript.

why_incorrect.a: variable is not a valid keyword in JavaScript.
why_incorrect.b: Alone it is correct, but option d includes both valid forms.
why_incorrect.c: Alone it is correct, but option d includes both valid forms.

questions.question: What will the following code return? typeof[]
questions.why_correct: In JavaScript, typeof [] returns "object" because arrays are objects.

why_incorrect.a: typeof does not return "array" for arrays.
why_incorrect.c: "list" is not a typeof return value.
why_incorrect.d: An array is not undefined, so typeof does not return "undefined".

questions.question: How do you add a new element to the end of an array in JavaScript?
questions.why_correct: The push method adds one or more elements to the end of an array.

why_incorrect.b: add is not a standard array method in JavaScript.
why_incorrect.c: append is not a method on JavaScript arrays.
why_incorrect.d: insert is not a standard JavaScript array method.

questions.question: What is a JavaScript Promise used for?
questions.why_correct: Promises represent the eventual completion or failure of an asynchronous operation and its resulting value.

why_incorrect.a: Promises are not a security mechanism.
why_incorrect.c: No feature can guarantee bug-free code.
why_incorrect.d: Promises help structure async code but do not inherently optimize performance.

questions.question: What does the following JavaScript code do? JSON.parse()

choices.a: Converts an object to a JSON string
choices.b: Parses a JSON string into a JavaScript object

questions.why_correct: JSON.parse takes a JSON-formatted string and converts it into a JavaScript value or object.

why_incorrect.a: Converting an object to a JSON string is done with JSON.stringify.
why_incorrect.c: It does parse, but its main purpose is conversion, not pure validation.
why_incorrect.d: It does not create files; it only parses strings in memory.

questions.question: What is the purpose of TypeScript?

choices.b: To add static typing to JavaScript

questions.why_correct: TypeScript is a superset of JavaScript that adds optional static typing and other features.

why_incorrect.a: TypeScript compiles down to JavaScript; it does not replace it at runtime.
why_incorrect.c: Performance improvements are indirect; its goal is type safety and tooling.
why_incorrect.d: It often adds complexity via types, not just simplification of syntax.

questions.question: Which SQL command is used to retrieve data from a database?
questions.why_correct: SELECT is the standard SQL command for querying data from tables.

why_incorrect.a: GET is not a standard SQL command.
why_incorrect.c: RETRIEVE is not a SQL keyword.
why_incorrect.d: FETCH is used in some contexts with cursors but not as the main query keyword.

questions.question: What is a primary key in a database table?

choices.a: The first column in the table
choices.b: A unique identifier for each record
choices.c: The most important data in a table

questions.why_correct: A primary key uniquely identifies each row in a table.

why_incorrect.a: It does not have to be the first column.
why_incorrect.c: Primary key is about uniqueness, not subjective importance.
why_incorrect.d: A reference to another table is usually a foreign key.

questions.question: Which SQL clause is used to filter records?
questions.why_correct: WHERE filters rows based on specified conditions.

why_incorrect.a: FILTER is not a standard SQL clause.
why_incorrect.c: HAVING filters groups after aggregation, not basic row filtering.
why_incorrect.d: CONDITION is not a SQL keyword for filtering.

questions.question: What is a JOIN used for in SQL?

choices.a: To combine rows from two or more tables
choices.c: To combine columns in a single table
choices.d: To join SQL with other programming languages

questions.why_correct: JOIN combines rows from two or more tables based on related columns.

why_incorrect.b: JOINs operate on tables, not on entire databases.
why_incorrect.c: Combining columns in a single table does not require a JOIN.
why_incorrect.d: JOIN has nothing to do with combining SQL with other languages.

questions.question: What is Hatch primarily used for?
questions.why_correct: Hatch is a tool focused on Python project management and packaging workflows.

why_incorrect.a: It is not primarily a frontend build tool.
why_incorrect.c: It is not a database migration tool.
why_incorrect.d: It is not focused on API testing.

questions.question: Which command initializes a new Hatch project?
questions.why_correct: hatch new is used to create a new Hatch-based project.

why_incorrect.b: hatch init is not the standard command for starting a new project here.
why_incorrect.c: hatch create is not the documented initialization command.
why_incorrect.d: hatch start is not the correct subcommand for creating a project.

questions.question: What language is FastAPI built for?
questions.why_correct: FastAPI is a modern web framework for building APIs in Python.

why_incorrect.a: FastAPI is not a JavaScript framework.
why_incorrect.c: It is not built for Java.
why_incorrect.d: It is not built for Ruby.

questions.question: What is a key feature of FastAPI?
questions.why_correct: FastAPI automatically generates interactive API docs using OpenAPI and Swagger UI.

why_incorrect.b: FastAPI integrates with ORMs but does not include a built-in one.
why_incorrect.c: Server-side rendering is not its primary feature.
why_incorrect.d: It does not specifically handle microservices orchestration.

questions.question: How does FastAPI handle request validation?
questions.why_correct: FastAPI uses Pydantic models to define and validate request data.

why_incorrect.a: You can validate manually, but the frameworkâ€™s main mechanism is Pydantic models.

why_incorrect.d: FastAPI has strong validation support through Pydantic.

questions.question: What is the purpose of dependency injection in FastAPI?

choices.c: To share objects across different parts of the app

questions.why_correct: Dependency injection is used to share and manage resources like DB connections and reduce repeated setup code.

why_incorrect.a: This is true, but not the only purpose.
why_incorrect.b: This is also true, but incomplete alone.
why_incorrect.c: Sharing objects is part of it, but not the whole story.

questions.question: What is JSX in React?

choices.b: A JavaScript extension that allows HTML-like syntax in JavaScript

questions.why_correct: JSX lets you write HTML-like markup directly in JavaScript, which React transforms to element creation calls.

why_incorrect.a: JSX is not related to databases.
why_incorrect.c: It is not a styling framework.
why_incorrect.d: It is not a testing library.

questions.question: What is a React component?

choices.b: A JavaScript function or class that returns UI elements

questions.why_correct: React components are functions or classes that return elements describing UI.

why_incorrect.a: CSS files contain styles, not React components.
why_incorrect.c: Pure HTML templates are not React components.
why_incorrect.d: Bundler configs (like Webpack configs) are not React components.

questions.question: What hook is used to manage state in a functional component?
questions.why_correct: useState is the primary React hook used to manage local state in functional components.

why_incorrect.a: useStatus is not a standard React hook.
why_incorrect.c: useMemory is not a React hook.
why_incorrect.d: useData is not a built-in React hook.

questions.question: What is the purpose of the useEffect hook?

choices.b: To perform side effects in functional components

questions.why_correct: useEffect runs side effects such as data fetching, subscriptions, and manual DOM mutations.

why_incorrect.a: Animations can be implemented inside useEffect, but that is not its core purpose.
why_incorrect.c: Props are read-only and should not be modified; useEffect does not change props directly.
why_incorrect.d: It may indirectly affect performance, but its purpose is managing side effects.

questions.question: How do you pass data from a parent to a child component in React?
questions.why_correct: Props are the standard way to pass data from a parent component to a child.

why_incorrect.a: Global variables are not the React-recommended method and break encapsulation.
why_incorrect.c: Context is used for global/shared state, but simple parent-to-child transfer is done via props.
why_incorrect.d: Direct DOM manipulation bypasses React's data flow and is not how you pass data.

questions.question: What is React's Virtual DOM?

choices.a: A complete separate DOM used for testing
choices.b: A lightweight copy of the actual DOM for performance optimization
choices.d: A DOM alternative that doesn't use HTML

questions.why_correct: The Virtual DOM is an in-memory representation of the actual DOM that allows efficient diffing and updates.

why_incorrect.a: It is not a separate DOM used just for testing.
why_incorrect.c: It is not related to 3D rendering.
why_incorrect.d: It still results in manipulation of the real HTML DOM.

questions.question: What is ShadCN?

choices.b: A UI component library for React
choices.c: A collection of accessible and customizable UI components

why_incorrect.a: It is more than just a CSS framework; it focuses on ready-to-use components.

questions.question: How are ShadCN components installed?

choices.a: Via npm install as standard packages
choices.b: Using a CLI that copies the component code into your project

questions.question: What is Next.js?

choices.b: A React framework with server-side rendering capabilities

questions.why_correct: Next.js is a React framework that supports server-side rendering, static site generation, and more.

why_incorrect.a: Next.js is not primarily for state management.
why_incorrect.c: It is not a CSS preprocessor.
why_incorrect.d: It is not a testing framework.

questions.question: How do you create a new page in Next.js App Router?

choices.b: Adding a route to the routes.config.js file
choices.c: Creating a page.js file in a directory under app/

questions.why_correct: In the App Router, a route is defined by creating a page.js file inside a folder under app/.

questions.question: What is the purpose of the getServerSideProps function in Next.js?

choices.b: To fetch data at request time on the server

questions.question: What is the key difference between pages/ and app/ directories in Next.js 13+?

choices.b: app/ uses the new App Router with RSC support
choices.c: pages/ supports API routes while app/ doesn't

questions.question: What is Docker?
questions.why_correct: Docker is a containerization platform that packages applications and dependencies into containers.

why_incorrect.a: Docker is not a programming language.

questions.question: What is a Docker container?

questions.question: What file defines how to build a Docker image?

questions.question: What are GitHub Actions used for?

questions.question: Where are GitHub Actions workflow files stored in a repository?

questions.question: What Git command shows the commit history?

questions.question: What is a Git branch?

questions.question: What does TDD stand for?

questions.question: In project management, what is a sprint?

choices.a: A quick meeting to resolve blockers
choices.b: A time-boxed period during which specific work is completed

questions.why_correct: A sprint is a fixed-length, time-boxed period where a team works to complete a set of items.

questions.question: Which SQL clause is used to sort results?

why_incorrect.c: ARRANGE BY is not a SQL clause.

questions.question: What is the purpose of the SQL UPDATE statement?
questions.why_correct: UPDATE modifies existing records in a table that match a condition.

questions.question: What is the primary purpose of an API?

choices.b: To define how software components interact

questions.question: Which HTTP method is idempotent, meaning multiple identical requests have the same effect as a single request?

why_incorrect.b: Image display is done via or related elements.
why_incorrect.c: It is not specifically a navigation frame.
why_incorrect.d: The term 'framed section' is vague; <iframe> embeds external content.

questions.question: Which HTML tag is used to create a form?
questions.why_correct: <form> defines an HTML form for user input.

why_incorrect.a: <input> is used for individual form controls, not the form container.
why_incorrect.c: <fieldset> groups form controls, but does not define the form itself.
why_incorrect.d: <formfield> is not a standard HTML tag.

questions.question: How do you add a background color to all <h1> elements in CSS?
questions.why_correct: h1 { ... } targets all <h1> elements.

why_incorrect.a: h1.all would target elements with tag h1 and class all, not all h1s.
why_incorrect.c: all.h1 is not a meaningful selector.
why_incorrect.d: .h1 targets elements with class="h1", not all <h1> tags.

questions.question: Which CSS property controls the size of text?
questions.why_correct: font-size sets the size of the font.

why_incorrect.a: text-size is not a standard CSS property.
why_incorrect.c: text-style is not a standard property.
why_incorrect.d: font-style is used for italic/normal/oblique, not size.

questions.question: What is the purpose of CSS Grid?

choices.c: To add grid lines to elements

questions.why_correct: CSS Grid is designed for two-dimensional layouts, controlling rows and columns.

why_incorrect.a: One-dimensional layouts are the focus of Flexbox.
why_incorrect.c: Grid lines are a visual concept, but Grid's purpose is broader layout control.
why_incorrect.d: Animations are managed with animation and transition properties, not Grid.

questions.question: How do you center an element horizontally in CSS?
questions.why_correct: margin: 0 auto; horizontally centers a block element with a defined width.

why_incorrect.a: margin: center; is not valid CSS.
why_incorrect.b: margin: auto 0; sets vertical auto margins, not horizontal.
why_incorrect.d: align is not a valid CSS property for centering.

questions.question: Which CSS property is used to control the spacing between lines of text?
questions.why_correct: line-height controls the vertical spacing between lines of text.

why_incorrect.a: line-spacing is not a standard CSS property.
why_incorrect.b: text-spacing is not the property used for line spacing.
why_incorrect.d: text-height is not a valid CSS property.

questions.question: What is a CSS preprocessor?

choices.a: A tool that processes CSS after it's written
choices.b: A program that processes CSS before it's sent to the browser

questions.why_correct: A CSS preprocessor (like SASS or LESS) compiles enhanced syntax into standard CSS before the browser sees it.

why_incorrect.a: They are used before, not after, delivering CSS to the browser.
why_incorrect.c: They are generally build tools, not browser extensions.
why_incorrect.d: They can aid organization but are not just an optimization trick.

questions.question: How do you declare a constant in JavaScript?
questions.why_correct: const declares a constant whose binding cannot be reassigned.

why_incorrect.a: var declares a function-scoped variable, not a constant.
why_incorrect.b: constant is not a valid keyword in JavaScript.
why_incorrect.c: let declares a block-scoped variable that can be reassigned.

questions.question: What is the correct way to check if "x" is equal to 5 in JavaScript?
questions.why_correct: === checks for strict equality (same value and type) and is recommended.

why_incorrect.a: This assigns 5 to x instead of comparing.
why_incorrect.b: == allows type coercion and can cause subtle bugs, though it still compares equality.
why_incorrect.d: This is not valid JavaScript syntax.

questions.question: What will the following JavaScript code return? typeof(undefined)
questions.why_correct: typeof undefined returns the string "undefined".

why_incorrect.a: "object" is returned for null, not undefined.
why_incorrect.c: typeof null is "object", not "null".
why_incorrect.d: typeof always returns a string; it does not throw here.

questions.question: What is a closure in JavaScript?

choices.a: A way to close browser windows
choices.b: A function bundled with references to its surrounding state
choices.c: A method to end JavaScript execution

questions.why_correct: A closure is a function that retains access to lexical scope even when called outside it.

why_incorrect.a: Window closing is unrelated to closures.
why_incorrect.c: Execution ending is not what closures do.
why_incorrect.d: Closures may be used in security patterns but are not inherently a security feature.

questions.question: How do you handle errors in JavaScript?
questions.why_correct: try/catch is the standard syntax for handling exceptions in JavaScript.

why_incorrect.b: error/handle is not valid syntax.
why_incorrect.c: check/error is not a JavaScript construct.
why_incorrect.d: try/error is not valid syntax.

questions.question: What is the main difference between JavaScript and TypeScript?

choices.a: TypeScript supports classes while JavaScript doesn't
choices.b: TypeScript has static typing while JavaScript has dynamic typing
choices.c: TypeScript runs in browsers while JavaScript needs compiling
choices.d: TypeScript supports modules while JavaScript doesn't

questions.why_correct: TypeScript adds static typing and type checking on top of JavaScript.

why_incorrect.a: Modern JavaScript also supports classes.
why_incorrect.c: TypeScript must be compiled to JavaScript to run in browsers.
why_incorrect.d: JavaScript also supports modules (ES modules).

questions.question: Which SQL statement is used to extract data from a database?
questions.why_correct: SELECT is the standard SQL statement to query and extract data.

why_incorrect.a: EXTRACT is not the general statement for querying rows.
why_incorrect.c: GET is not a standard SQL keyword.
why_incorrect.d: OPEN is used for cursors in some systems, not general queries.

questions.question: How do you filter results in SQL?
questions.why_correct: WHERE restricts rows returned by the query based on a condition.

why_incorrect.a: FILTER BY is not standard SQL syntax.
why_incorrect.c: HAVING filters groups after aggregation, not base rows.
why_incorrect.d: CONDITION BY filter is not a valid SQL clause.

questions.question: What does the SQL GROUP BY clause do?

choices.a: Groups the result by a specific column
choices.b: Filters groups in a result set
choices.c: Orders the result by a specific column
choices.d: Joins tables together by a specific column

questions.why_correct: GROUP BY collects rows into groups based on one or more columns.

why_incorrect.b: HAVING is used to filter groups after grouping.
why_incorrect.c: ORDER BY controls sorting, not grouping.
why_incorrect.d: JOIN clauses combine tables; GROUP BY does not join tables.

questions.question: What is an SQL injection attack?

choices.a: Inserting malicious code into SQL statements
choices.b: Forcing a database to inject new records
choices.c: Adding unauthorized tables to a database
choices.d: Overloading a database with too many queries

questions.why_correct: SQL injection is a technique where attackers inject malicious SQL code into queries.

why_incorrect.b: Record insertion may be a consequence but not the definition.
why_incorrect.c: Adding tables is not the essence of injection.
why_incorrect.d: Overloading with queries describes a DoS attack, not injection.

questions.question: What task does Hatch help with during Python development?
questions.why_correct: Hatch assists with Python package creation, configuration, and publishing.

why_incorrect.a: Hatch is not a frontend build tool.
why_incorrect.c: Cloud deployment is handled by other tools.
why_incorrect.d: It does not focus on ML training.

questions.question: What can Hatch manage for Python projects?
questions.why_correct: Hatch can manage project-specific development environments.

why_incorrect.a: Git is used for repository management, not Hatch.
why_incorrect.c: Authentication systems are application-level concerns, not Hatch features.
why_incorrect.d: Database servers are external to Hatch.

questions.question: What makes FastAPI "fast"?

choices.b: It's based on Starlette and Pydantic for high performance
choices.c: It only works with simple data types
choices.d: It limits the number of concurrent users

questions.why_correct: FastAPI uses Starlette and Pydantic, which are designed for speed and efficiency.

why_incorrect.a: FastAPI is Python-based; it may rely on performant libraries but not purely C++.
why_incorrect.c: It supports complex nested data via Pydantic models.
why_incorrect.d: It does not speed up by limiting users; it is optimized for concurrency.

questions.question: What is a key feature of FastAPI?
questions.why_correct: FastAPI automatically generates interactive API docs like Swagger UI and ReDoc.

why_incorrect.a: FastAPI can use templates, but this is not its key distinctive feature.
why_incorrect.c: Payment processing is not built in.
why_incorrect.d: FastAPI can work without any database at all.

questions.question: How does FastAPI handle request validation?

choices.b: Using Pydantic models and type hints

questions.why_correct: FastAPI uses type hints and Pydantic models to automatically validate data.

why_incorrect.a: Manual validation is possible but not the primary approach.
why_incorrect.c: Regex can be used, but validation is much broader via Pydantic.
why_incorrect.d: FastAPI has strong built-in validation support.

questions.question: What is the purpose of the @app.get() decorator in FastAPI?

choices.b: To define a route that handles GET requests
choices.c: To retrieve data from a database

questions.why_correct: @app.get() declares a route function that responds to HTTP GET requests.

why_incorrect.a: It is not a generic 'getter' method like in OOP.
why_incorrect.c: The route may retrieve data, but database access is not inherent to the decorator.
why_incorrect.d: Configuration retrieval is not the purpose of this decorator.

questions.question: What is the React Virtual DOM?

choices.b: A lightweight copy of the actual DOM for performance optimization
choices.c: A DOM that only exists in virtual reality applications
choices.d: The DOM created by virtual components

questions.why_correct: The Virtual DOM is an in-memory representation of the real DOM used to efficiently compute updates.

why_incorrect.a: It is not a physical component.
why_incorrect.c: It is unrelated to virtual reality.
why_incorrect.d: While components are virtual representations, 'Virtual DOM' refers specifically to Reactâ€™s diffing structure.

questions.question: How do you create a React functional component?

choices.b: By defining a function that returns JSX
choices.c: By creating an instance of React.Function

questions.why_correct: A functional component is simply a function that returns JSX.

why_incorrect.a: Extending React.Component is used for class components.
why_incorrect.c: React.Function is not a real API.
why_incorrect.d: createReactFunction() is not a built-in method.

questions.question: What is the purpose of React's useState hook?

choices.c: To check if a component is being used
choices.d: To determine if a user is active

questions.why_correct: useState introduces state into functional components and provides a setter.

why_incorrect.a: State managed by useState is not static; it can change and trigger re-renders.
why_incorrect.c: It does not check component usage.
why_incorrect.d: User activity tracking is not its purpose.

questions.question: When would you use the useEffect hook with an empty dependency array?

choices.a: When you want the effect to run on every render
choices.b: When you want the effect to run only when a specific state changes
choices.c: When you want the effect to run only once after the initial render
choices.d: When you want to skip the effect completely

questions.why_correct: An empty dependency array means the effect runs once after the component mounts.

why_incorrect.a: Without a dependency array, the effect runs on every render.
why_incorrect.b: You would include that state variable in the dependency array.
why_incorrect.d: To skip the effect, you would not define it at all.

questions.question: What does the React Fragment allow you to do?

choices.a: Split a component into multiple files
choices.b: Group children without adding extra nodes to the DOM

questions.why_correct: Fragments let you return multiple children from a component without adding an extra wrapper element.

why_incorrect.a: File organization is independent of React Fragments.
why_incorrect.c: They do not specifically handle caching.
why_incorrect.d: They are not about 'partial components' but grouping children.

questions.question: How do you handle form input in React?

choices.c: Using state to store input values
choices.d: Forms are not supported in React

questions.why_correct: Form inputs are often controlled via state, making React the source of truth.

why_incorrect.a: React does not have a special built-in Form component for handling all forms.
why_incorrect.b: Direct DOM manipulation goes against React's declarative model.
why_incorrect.d: React fully supports forms through JSX elements.

questions.question: What is the primary design goal of ShadCN?

choices.a: To provide the most components possible
choices.b: To offer accessible components with control over their code
choices.c: To create the smallest bundle size
choices.d: To eliminate the need for CSS

questions.why_correct: ShadCN focuses on accessible components where you own and control the source code.

why_incorrect.a: The library emphasizes quality and control, not sheer quantity.
why_incorrect.c: Bundle size is important but not the stated primary goal.
why_incorrect.d: It still relies on CSS (via Tailwind).

questions.question: How would you install a button component from ShadCN?
questions.why_correct: The ShadCN CLI uses commands like npx shadcn-ui add button to copy component code.

why_incorrect.a: ShadCN is not typically used as a single npm package per component.
why_incorrect.c: This is not the documented CLI command.
why_incorrect.d: This is not a valid ShadCN package pattern.

questions.question: What technology is ShadCN built with?
questions.why_correct: ShadCN uses Tailwind CSS utility classes for styling.

why_incorrect.a: It does not rely solely on hand-written vanilla CSS.
why_incorrect.c: Styled Components is not its base styling solution.
why_incorrect.d: CSS Modules are not its primary mechanism.

questions.question: What is the App Router in Next.js?

choices.b: A new routing system introduced in Next.js 13
choices.c: A component for navigating between pages
choices.d: A tool for managing route transitions

questions.why_correct: The App Router is Next.js 13's new routing system using the app/ directory and server components.

why_incorrect.a: It is part of Next.js core, not third-party.
why_incorrect.c: Navigation components use the router, but the App Router is the overall system.
why_incorrect.d: It does more than manage route transitions.

questions.question: How do you create an API route in Next.js App Router?

choices.a: Create a file in the pages/api directory
choices.b: Create a route.js file in the app/api directory
choices.d: Add an api property to the next.config.js file

questions.why_correct: In the App Router, API routes are created by defining route.js (or route.ts) files under app/api/.

why_incorrect.a: pages/api is used in the older Pages Router.
why_incorrect.c: There is no built-in createApiRoute() function.
why_incorrect.d: next.config.js does not define API endpoints directly.

questions.question: What is a Server Component in Next.js?

choices.a: A component that only runs on a dedicated server
choices.b: A component that's rendered on the server and doesn't include client-side JavaScript
choices.c: A component that manages server connections
choices.d: A backend service that serves components

questions.why_correct: Server Components are rendered on the server and sent as HTML, without client-side JS bundle.

why_incorrect.a: They are not tied to a special server type; they are a rendering mode.
why_incorrect.c: They may fetch or manage data but are defined by where they render.
why_incorrect.d: They are components, not separate services.

questions.question: How do you fetch data in Next.js Server Components?

choices.c: By directly using async/await or fetch

questions.why_correct: Server Components can use async/await and fetch directly at the top level since they run on the server.

why_incorrect.a: useEffect is a client-side hook and not used in Server Components.
why_incorrect.b: useState manages state, not data fetching alone.
why_incorrect.d: getServerSideProps is used in the Pages Router, not Server Components in the App Router.

questions.question: What is a Dockerfile?

choices.a: A container that stores Docker images
choices.b: A text file with instructions to build a Docker image

questions.why_correct: A Dockerfile contains the commands Docker uses to assemble an image.

why_incorrect.a: Images are stored separately, not in a Dockerfile.
why_incorrect.c: Docker GUIs exist but are not Dockerfiles.
why_incorrect.d: Configurations are not stored as a database in Dockerfile.

questions.question: Which command builds a Docker image?
questions.why_correct: docker build reads a Dockerfile to build an image.

why_incorrect.a: docker create creates a container from an image.
why_incorrect.c: docker compile is not a standard command.
why_incorrect.d: docker make is not a standard command.

questions.question: What is Docker Hub?

choices.b: A registry service for Docker images
choices.c: A tool for managing Docker networks

questions.why_correct: Docker Hub is a cloud-based registry where Docker images can be stored and shared.

why_incorrect.a: It is a remote registry, not a local environment.
why_incorrect.c: Network management is handled by Docker itself or Docker Compose, not Docker Hub.
why_incorrect.d: Container orchestration is provided by tools like Kubernetes or Docker Swarm.

questions.question: How do containers differ from virtual machines?

choices.a: Containers are faster and more lightweight but share the host OS kernel
choices.b: Containers require more resources but offer better isolation
choices.c: Containers run only specific applications while VMs run entire systems

questions.why_correct: Containers share the host OS kernel and are lighter, making them faster to start and use fewer resources.

why_incorrect.b: Containers typically require fewer resources than VMs.
why_incorrect.c: While containers usually package specific apps, this is not the key difference described in the question.
why_incorrect.d: There are clear architectural differences between containers and VMs.

questions.question: What is the purpose of GitHub Actions?

choices.b: To automate software workflows like CI/CD

questions.why_correct: GitHub Actions is designed to automate workflows, including CI/CD pipelines.

why_incorrect.a: Code reviews are done by maintainers, not Actions themselves.
why_incorrect.c: GitHub Pages hosts sites; Actions may help deploy but hosting is separate.
why_incorrect.d: Repository management is core GitHub functionality, not specific to Actions.

questions.question: How do you specify when a GitHub Actions workflow should run?
questions.why_correct: The on property defines which events (push, pull_request, schedule, etc.) trigger the workflow.

why_incorrect.a: schedule is one option under on, but not the main key.
why_incorrect.b: when is not a recognized workflow key.
why_incorrect.d: trigger is not the correct property name.

questions.question: What are GitHub Actions runners?

choices.c: Special GitHub accounts with execution privileges

questions.why_correct: Runners are machines (hosted or self-hosted) that run the workflow jobs.

why_incorrect.a: Scripts may run on runners, but the runner itself is the machine.
why_incorrect.c: They are not user accounts, but compute resources.
why_incorrect.d: Workflows may use container images, but runners are the environment executing them.
